member.name: SYSTEM_INFO
member.summary: Contains information about the current computer system. This includes the architecture and type of the processor, the number of processors in the system, the page size, and other such information.

member.name: SYSTEM_INFO.DUMMYUNIONNAME.dwOemId
member.summary: An obsolete member that is retained for compatibility. Applications should use the wProcessorArchitecture branch of the union.

summary.para: The processor architecture of the installed operating system. This member can be one of the following values.

member.name: SYSTEM_INFO.DUMMYUNIONNAME.DUMMYSTRUCTNAME.wReserved
member.summary: This member is reserved for future use.

member.name: SYSTEM_INFO.dwPageSize
member.summary: The page size and the granularity of page protection and commitment. This is the page size used by the function.

member.name: SYSTEM_INFO.lpMinimumApplicationAddress
member.summary: A pointer to the lowest memory address accessible to applications and dynamic-link libraries (DLLs).

member.name: SYSTEM_INFO.lpMaximumApplicationAddress
member.summary: A pointer to the highest memory address accessible to applications and DLLs.

member.name: SYSTEM_INFO.dwActiveProcessorMask
member.summary: A mask representing the set of processors configured into the system. Bit 0 is processor 0; bit 31 is processor 31.

summary.para: The number of logical processors in the current group. To retrieve the current processor group, use the function.
summary.div: Note For information about the physical processors shared by logical processors, call with the RelationshipType parameter set to RelationProcessorPackage (3).

summary.para: An obsolete member that is retained for compatibility. Use the wProcessorArchitecture, wProcessorLevel, and wProcessorRevision members to determine the type of processor.

member.name: SYSTEM_INFO.dwAllocationGranularity
member.summary: The granularity for the starting address at which virtual memory can be allocated. For more information, see .

summary.para: The architecture-dependent processor level. It should be used only for display purposes. To determine the feature set of a processor, use the function.
If wProcessorArchitecture is PROCESSOR_ARCHITECTURE_INTEL, wProcessorLevel is defined by the CPU vendor.
If wProcessorArchitecture is PROCESSOR_ARCHITECTURE_IA64, wProcessorLevel is set to 1.
The architecture-dependent processor revision. The following table shows how the revision value is assembled for each type of processor architecture.

listheader.description:
The high byte is the model and the low byte is the stepping. For example, if the value is xxyy, the model number and stepping can be displayed as follows:
Model xx, Stepping yy

A value of the form xxyz.
If xx is equal to 0xFF, y - 0xA is the model number, and z is the stepping identifier.
If xx is not equal to 0xFF, xx + 'A' is the stepping letter and yz is the minor stepping.
